intro.p: You're the marketing director for {{company}}, and your team has just finished its test-market analysis for your brand-new product, {{product}}: "{{slogan}}".

The data your team gathered tested {{n}} different price points for selling {{product}}, and predicted the net profit that {{company}} would make selling at each price point. The data is shown in the table below.

If you can model this profit as a quadratic function of unit price, you think to yourself, you can figure out how to make the most profit possible... and that maximum is probably greater than any of the points in this data set!

content.p: Using technology, you graph, and determine a quadratic function y = P(x) = {{pfunc}} that best fits, these {{n}} data points.

image.description: Graph of quadratic model for this data

content.p: In 1-2 sentences, explain: What is the leading coefficient in your equation model? What can we learn about {{product}} from the fact that this leading coefficient is negative instead of positive?

outtro.p: The quadratic model for these data points is P(x) = {{pfunc}}.

The leading coefficient being negative reflects the fact that this quadratic function reaches a maximum value at its vertex, instead of a negative. (The profit available from selling {{product}} has an upper limit.)

content.p: In 1-2 sentences, explain: What is the constant term in your equation model? What, specifically, does this number mean about the profits of selling {{product}}?
(Hint: What value of x produces this value of y?)

outtro.p: The constant term tells us that, if we gave away all the {{product}} desired in the market for free (charged a unit price of x=0 dollars), we would lose ${{absc}} thousand dollars of profit. This is the y-intercept of our function model.

content.p: At what unit price(s) would we make zero profit from selling {{product}}? Set up an equation whose solution would answer this question, then use the quadratic formula to solve it. Round your answers to two decimal places.

outtro.p: The breakeven prices from solving {{pfunc}} = 0 are approximately \${{r1}} and \${{r2}} per unit, respectively.

content.p: Determine the vertex of your quadratic function. Then, write 1-2 sentences to explain to your CEO (who is not a math professor): what does this vertex mean about how you should set the price for {{product}}? And why?

outtro.p: The vertex for our quadratic model has coordinates ({{vx}},{{vy}}). Since by part (a) we know this is a maximum point for our function, we can say the following to our CEO:
"The maximum amount of profit available for selling {{product}} is \${{vy}} thousand dollars. We can achieve this profit by charging \${{vx}} per unit for {{product}}."
